title: CLARIN Corpora for Parliamentary Discourse Research

segmentation: Good morning everyone.
Welcome to our workshop.

Cropping up in the recent years.

Empirical research for which we badly need richly annotated corpora as well as integrative analytical tools for the people to be able to tackle these large datasets without necessarily having a technical background.
When starting this overview, we have identified several issues.

We have realized that when people start developing parliamentary corpora, these efforts are usually not very well coordinated, which is why the resulting corpora are not uniformly sampled, annotated, formatted, and documented.
This is why it is very hard to make comparative research or even.
Repeat the same kind of research questions on a different data set.

First and foremost, we propose that from the very early stages of compiling such corpora we need to focus on the intended use and users, which means that corpora.

Need to be annotated, formatted, documented and released in such a way that they are valuable for researchers, not only from our own community or from the same background as the Corpus development initiative start, but from very diverse research backgrounds ranging from history to political science and everything in between.
What is needed for this to be successful is that there really needs to be.
A comprehensive data and metadata inclusion policy in place because sampling of what it is that you are researching is very, very important for certain research communities such as social scientists.

And use the corpora that exist.
Second set of important points revolve around the optimization of user interface is an good documentation in the Clarion community.

Prevent interface fatigue so that researchers don't have to switch between too many interfaces as well as support comparative research using different datasets.

Alization tools.
